description.narrative:
Plan Sverige har ansökt om 32 144 597 SEK för att implementera en fas 2 av "The African Children's Charter Project" (ACCP) i Afrika under åren 2018-2020. Genom att främja implementeringen av den afrikanska barnrättskonventionen syftar projektet till att bidra till en långsiktig förbättring av barns liv i Afrika. Detta kommer att ske genom att 1) stärka kapaciteten hos den Afrikanska expertkommitté som är knuten till den afrikanska barnrättskonventionen, "The African Committee of Experts on the Right and Welfare of the Child" (ACERWC), 2) integrera barns rättigheter i beslut och verksamhet inom den Afrikanska Unionen (AU) och 3) stötta civilsamhället att arbeta tillsammans med AU för att främja och skydda barns rättigheter och välmående.
Sida är ensam bidragsgivare till projektet och har tidigare stöttat en första fas av ACCP (2011-2014) samt en överbryggningsperiod åren 2015-2017. Större delen av projektets aktiviteter kommer att utföras av ett konsortium som bildats under projektets första fas. I konsortiet ingår förutom Plan Sverige och Plans Pan-Afrikanska kontor i Etiopien, Svenska Rädda Barnen och Rädda Barnens kontor i Kenya och Senegal, The Dullah Omar Institute for Constitutional Law, Governance and Human Rights (Sydafrika), The African Child Policy Forum (Etiopien) och The Institute for Human Rights and Development in Africa (Gambia). ACERWC stöttas också via ett projekt finansierat a Europeiska Unionen. De båda projekten samordnas för ökad effektivitet och genomslag.

Plan Sweden has applied to Sida for funding of 32 144 597 SEK to carry out a phase 2 of the "African Children's Charter Project" (ACCP) during the period 2018-2020. By promoting the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child, the project aspires to contribute to a long-term improvement of children's life on the African continent. This will be done by 1) strengthening the capacity of the African Committee of Experts on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACERWC), 2) integrating children's rights in decisions and actions within the African Union and 3) supporting the civil society to work together with the African Union to promote and protect children's rights and welfare.
Sida will be the project's only funder and has previously supported a first phase of the ACCP (2011-2014) as well as a bridging period between 2015-2017. A great majority of the project's activities will be implemented by a consortium of non-governmental organisations which was formed during ACCP in phase 1. The consortium consist Plan Sweden and Plan's Pan-African Office in Ethiopia, Swedish Save the Children and ave the Childrens' offices in Kenya and Senegal, the Dullah Omar Institute for Constitutional Law, Governance and Human Rights (South Africa), the African Child Policy Forum (Ethiopia) and the Institute for Human Rights and Development in Africa (Gambia). ACERWC is also supported by a project funded by the European Union. The projects are coordinated for enhanced efficiency and impact.

The development internvention aspires to contribute to the realization of children's rights through facilitating and promoting the implementation of the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACRWC)by working towards three main outcomes: To strengthen the capacity of the African Committee of Experts on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACERWC) to implement its mandate, to promote the integration of childrens rights in the decisions and actions of the African Union's (AU) bodies, institutions and mechanisms with particular focus on the African Charter on Human Rights and People's Rights (ACHPR), African Court of Human and People's Rights (AfCHPR), African Union Commission (AUC), Regional Economic Communities (RECs) and the Peace and Security Council (PSC) and to support civil society to engage with the AU mechanisms, especially the ACERWC to promote and protect childrens rights and welfare.

description.narrative:
The African Child Charter Project (ACCP) has made significant progress through the years towards the achievement of its objectives through the consortium partners who contributed to the strengthening of the human and technical capacity of the (African Committee on the Right and Welfare of the Child) ACERWC, which culminated in better execution of the Committees mandate on promotion and ensuring the implementation and protection of the rights of the child as enshrined in the ACRWC (Articles 32 46). The support from the ACCP to the consortium members interventions led to the enhanced quality and turnaround times for concluding observations on state reports, General Comments and review of individual communications and Children Affected by Armed Conflict (CAAC) issues submitted to the Committee. The Committees visibility has been greatly enhanced, with its communications procedures strengthened resulting in the improved utilization of the Committee as an accountability mechanism for children rights by other AU organs, Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), children, governments and other actors in the child rights sector.
Further, the ACCP strengthened the CSO Forum to become the premier platform in the African continent that has institutionalized CSOs engagement with the ACERWC and other AU agencies. The engagements of CSOs through the CSO Forum has resulted in increased accountability by governments on commitments owed to children and for violations of their rights through the implementation of advocacy initiatives and positively influencing policies, laws, and programmes affecting children. They also contribute to the promotion of childrens rights by raising awareness and building the capacity of government, communities, children and other actors on childrens rights issues; as well as fostering meaningful and effective children participation in decision making mechanisms.
However, it is indicated that the reduction in the number of State Parties reporting to the ACERWC is one of the key hindrances during the life of the ACCP from 2018-2021. 2020 and 2021 have exacerbated the challenges during the reporting period as face-to face meetings as well as engagements with States were limited due to the restrictions posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Reports from the project recommend that there is a need for the ACERWC to secure a continental guarantor to provide the requisite technical support and sponsorship on State reporting process similar to the support provided by the United Nations Child Fund (UNICEF) and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) under the UNCRC reporting system.
When it comes to sustainability and exit, the project exit strategy was completed in 2020 and 2021 through a participatory process. The process identified various key aspects to be addressed including the institutional capacity strengthening of the ACERWC considering the lack of human resources and long-term funding for staff within the ACERWC emphasizing the move to the Kingdom of Lesotho. Proposed mitigation strategy for this includes an assessment of filling in the human resource gaps in the ACERWC in the long term beyond 2021. There are several different options which include the projects directly funding the ACERWC secretariat for staffing, with a clear cut-off date for the AU to take up funding for the positions as per the approved structure or to keep the arrangement as is under the current work plans with a reduced number of staffs to be seconded.
The ACERWC and the CSO Forum, which together make up the major beneficiaries of the ACCP, have no clearly articulated and sustainable resource mobilization strategies. However, the Committee has managed to secure some funding from the EU and GIZ to continue the implementation of the strategic plan. According to the report, within the ACERWC, the fundraising plan and sustainable resource mobilization will be a key component of the 3rd Strategy (2020-2024). Sustainable resource mobilization will focus on securing resources from the AU Member States and external donors. In 2021 the CSO Forum embarked on the process of developing their Strategic Plan that will have a sustainable resource mobilization strategy as part of the documents under development as well as establish a permanent Secretariat to coordinate efforts on sustainability.
